section.name: Project File
section.p: The project file format is very similar to that of Ant 1. The root element of the project file must be a <project> element. It can take the following attributes:

tr.td: The base-name of the project file, with the extension removed.
The base directory for the project. The base directory is used to resolve all relative file names used in the project file.
The directory containing the project file.
The name of the default target.
The project file version that the project is written for.

section.p: A <project> element can contain the following elements, in the order given below:

subsection.name: Project References
subsection.p: Project references allow the project to import, or reference, other projects. A <projectref> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: The name to use to identify the referenced project.
The path to the project file to reference.

subsection.p: The targets of a referenced project can be used in the depends list of a target in the referencing project, using the following syntax: project-name->target-name. Here is a simple example:
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0"> <!-- Reference another project --> <projectref name="subproject" location="subproject/build.xml"/>
<!-- Use the "compile" target from the referenced project --> <target name="main" depends="subproject->compile"> .. do some stuff .. </target> </project>

subsection.name: Library Imports
subsection.p: Library imports allow the project to import the tasks and data-types from an antlib. An <import> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: The name of the library to import. The ext directory of the Myrmidon distribution is searched for a library file with the given name, and an atl extension.
The type of definition to import. Values include task, and data-type.
The name of the type to import.

subsection.p: If the type and name attributes are not provided, the entire contents of the antlib are imported.
The following example import the <my-task> task from the my-tasks antlib.
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0"> <!-- Import task <my-task> from the 'my-tasks' antlib. --> <import library="my-tasks" type="task" name="my-task"/>
<target name="main"> <my-task some-prop=".."/> </target> </project>

subsection.name: Implicit Tasks
subsection.p: Implicit tasks are run before any of the project's targets are run. Any task can be used, including <property> and data-type instances. Implicit tasks can be used to initialise the project. For example:
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0">
<property name="some-property" value="some value"/> <path id="classpath"> <fileset dir="lib"/> </path> <log>Set classpath to ${classpath}</log>
<target name="main"> .. do some stuff .. </target>
</project>

subsection.name: Targets
subsection.p: Targets have the same format as in Ant 1.x, though some of the behaviour is different. A <target> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: A comma-separated list of targets that this target depends on. This list can contain targets from referenced projects.
Only execute this target if the specified property is set, and not equal to false.
Do not execute this target if the specified property is set, and not equal to false.

Loads a set of properties from a file.
